overview: Veterinary Professional Practice 1 centres on developing the skills and competencies required for veterinary employability. Students will integrate aspects of anatomy, clinical skills and imaging to enable understanding and implementation of the diagnostic process and treatment procedures. Students will also gain and apply an understanding of the essential employability attributes, including developing effective relationships, enhancing procedural and client communication skills, considering financial, ethical and legal aspects of practice, and curating psychological resources including mindfulness and self-compassion. Students will learn about relationship-centred care and will use ethical frameworks to analyse and address professional ethical challenges. Upon completion of this and the subsequent related subject (Veterinary Professional Practice 2), students will be prepared for their transition into work-integrated curricular experiences in the profession (clinical intra- and extra-mural placements).

additional pre-requisite: Satisfactory completion of all subjects at DVM 1 level

Written peer review of two student mock consultations
150 words (each)
300 words (total). 150 words (each). Hurdle requirement:. Students must submit by the due date.

assessments.description: Transcription of the recording of student's own mock consultation. 750 words (equivalent). Hurdle requirement:. Students must submit by the due date.
assessments.timing: Due two weeks after communication practical

assessments.description: Written reflection on student's own mock consultation using peer feedback from two students and transcribed text. 400 words. Hurdle requirement:. Students must achieve a minimum mark of 50% for the written reflection on the mock consultation.
assessments.timing: Due two weeks after communication practical

assessments.description: Written examination. 1 hours. Hurdle requirement:. Students must achieve a minimum mark of 50% in the written examination to be eligible to pass the subject.

Semester 1.Contact hours: 51 hours of lectures, seminars and practical classes

Prescribed texts: There are no specifically prescribed or recommended texts for this subject.
